CreateAudienceModel.name: CreateAudienceModel
CreateAudienceModel.documentation: Defines the information necessary to create an audience model. An audience model is a machine learning model that Clean Rooms ML trains to measure similarity between users. Clean Rooms ML manages training and storing the audience model. The audience model can be used in multiple calls to the StartAudienceGenerationJob API.

CreateConfiguredAudienceModel.name: CreateConfiguredAudienceModel
CreateConfiguredAudienceModel.documentation: Defines the information necessary to create a configured audience model.

CreateTrainingDataset.name: CreateTrainingDataset
CreateTrainingDataset.documentation: Defines the information necessary to create a training dataset, or seed audience. In Clean Rooms ML, the TrainingDataset is metadata that points to a Glue table, which is read only during AudienceModel creation.

DeleteAudienceGenerationJob.name: DeleteAudienceGenerationJob
DeleteAudienceGenerationJob.documentation: Deletes the specified audience generation job, and removes all data associated with the job.

DeleteAudienceModel.name: DeleteAudienceModel
DeleteAudienceModel.documentation: Specifies an audience model that you want to delete. You can't delete an audience model if there are any configured audience models that depend on the audience model.

DeleteConfiguredAudienceModel.name: DeleteConfiguredAudienceModel
DeleteConfiguredAudienceModel.documentation: Deletes the specified configured audience model. You can't delete a configured audience model if there are any lookalike models that use the configured audience model. If you delete a configured audience model, it will be removed from any collaborations that it is associated to.

DeleteConfiguredAudienceModelPolicy.name: DeleteConfiguredAudienceModelPolicy
DeleteConfiguredAudienceModelPolicy.documentation: Deletes the specified configured audience model policy.

DeleteTrainingDataset.name: DeleteTrainingDataset
DeleteTrainingDataset.documentation: Specifies a training dataset that you want to delete. You can't delete a training dataset if there are any audience models that depend on the training dataset. In Clean Rooms ML, the TrainingDataset is metadata that points to a Glue table, which is read only during AudienceModel creation. This action deletes the metadata.

GetAudienceGenerationJob.name: GetAudienceGenerationJob
GetAudienceGenerationJob.documentation: Returns information about an audience generation job.

GetConfiguredAudienceModel.name: GetConfiguredAudienceModel
GetConfiguredAudienceModel.documentation: Returns information about a specified configured audience model.

GetConfiguredAudienceModelPolicy.name: GetConfiguredAudienceModelPolicy
GetConfiguredAudienceModelPolicy.documentation: Returns information about a configured audience model policy.

ListAudienceExportJobs.name: ListAudienceExportJobs
ListAudienceExportJobs.documentation: Returns a list of the audience export jobs.

ListAudienceGenerationJobs.name: ListAudienceGenerationJobs
ListAudienceGenerationJobs.documentation: Returns a list of audience generation jobs.

ListConfiguredAudienceModels.name: ListConfiguredAudienceModels
ListConfiguredAudienceModels.documentation: Returns a list of the configured audience models.

ListTagsForResource.name: ListTagsForResource
ListTagsForResource.documentation: Returns a list of tags for a provided resource.

PutConfiguredAudienceModelPolicy.name: PutConfiguredAudienceModelPolicy
PutConfiguredAudienceModelPolicy.documentation: Create or update the resource policy for a configured audience model.

StartAudienceExportJob.name: StartAudienceExportJob
StartAudienceExportJob.documentation: Export an audience of a specified size after you have generated an audience.

StartAudienceGenerationJob.name: StartAudienceGenerationJob
StartAudienceGenerationJob.documentation: Information necessary to start the audience generation job.

TagResource.name: TagResource
TagResource.documentation: Adds metadata tags to a specified resource.

UntagResource.name: UntagResource
UntagResource.documentation: Removes metadata tags from a specified resource.

UpdateConfiguredAudienceModel.name: UpdateConfiguredAudienceModel
UpdateConfiguredAudienceModel.documentation: Provides the information necessary to update a configured audience model. Updates that impact audience generation jobs take effect when a new job starts, but do not impact currently running jobs.

AccessDeniedException.documentation: You do not have sufficient access to perform this action.

s3Destination.documentation: The Amazon S3 bucket and path for the configured audience.

AudienceDestination.documentation: Defines the Amazon S3 bucket where the configured audience is stored.

audienceGenerationJobArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the audience generation job that was exported.

createTime.documentation: The time at which the audience export job was created.

description.documentation: The description of the audience export job.

name.documentation: The name of the audience export job.

outputLocation.documentation: The Amazon S3 bucket where the audience export is stored.

status.documentation: The status of the audience export job.

updateTime.documentation: The most recent time at which the audience export job was updated.

AudienceExportJobSummary.documentation: Provides information about the audience export job.

dataSource.documentation: The Amazon S3 bucket where the training data for the configured audience is stored.

roleArn.documentation: The ARN of the IAM role that can read the Amazon S3 bucket where the training data is stored.

AudienceGenerationJobDataSource.documentation: Defines the Amazon S3 bucket where the training data for the configured audience is stored.

audienceGenerationJobArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the audience generation job.

collaborationId.documentation: The identifier of the collaboration that contains this audience generation job.

configuredAudienceModelArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the configured audience model that was used for this audience generation job.

createTime.documentation: The time at which the audience generation job was created.

description.documentation: The description of the audience generation job.

name.documentation: The name of the audience generation job.

startedBy.documentation: The AWS Account that submitted the job.

status.documentation: The status of the audience generation job.

updateTime.documentation: The most recent time at which the audience generation job was updated.

AudienceGenerationJobSummary.documentation: Provides information about the configured audience generation job.

forTopKItemPredictions.documentation: The number of users that were used to generate these model metrics.

value.documentation: The value of the audience model metric

audienceModelArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the audience model.

createTime.documentation: The time at which the audience model was created.

trainingDatasetArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the training dataset that was used for the audience model.

updateTime.documentation: The most recent time at which the audience model was updated.

relevanceMetrics.documentation: The relevance scores of the generated audience.

AudienceQualityMetrics.documentation: Metrics that describe the quality of the generated audience.

type.documentation: Whether the audience size is defined in absolute terms or as a percentage. You can use the ABSOLUTE AudienceSize to configure out audience sizes using the count of identifiers in the output. You can use the Percentage AudienceSize to configure sizes in the range 1-100 percent.

AudienceSize.documentation: The size of the generated audience. Must match one of the sizes in the configured audience model.

audienceSizeBins.documentation: An array of the different audience output sizes.

audienceSizeType.documentation: Whether the audience output sizes are defined as an absolute number or a percentage.

AudienceSizeConfig.documentation: Configure the list of audience output sizes that can be created. A request to StartAudienceGenerationJob that uses this configured audience model must have an audienceSize selected from this list. You can use the ABSOLUTE AudienceSize to configure out audience sizes using the count of identifiers in the output. You can use the Percentage AudienceSize to configure sizes in the range 1-100 percent.

roleArn.documentation: The ARN of the IAM role that can write the Amazon S3 bucket.

ConfiguredAudienceModelOutputConfig.documentation: Configuration information necessary for the configure audience model output.

audienceModelArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the audience model that was used to create the configured audience model.

configuredAudienceModelArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the configured audience model that you are interested in.

createTime.documentation: The time at which the configured audience model was created.

description.documentation: The description of the configured audience model.

name.documentation: The name of the configured audience model.

outputConfig.documentation: The output configuration of the configured audience model.

status.documentation: The status of the configured audience model.

updateTime.documentation: The most recent time at which the configured audience model was updated.

ConflictException.documentation: A resource with that name already exists in this region.

kmsKeyArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the KMS key. This key is used to encrypt and decrypt customer-owned data in the trained ML model and the associated data.

name.documentation: The name of the audience model resource.

tags.documentation:
The optional metadata that you apply to the resource to help you categorize and organize them. Each tag consists of a key and an optional value, both of which you define.

The following basic restrictions apply to tags:

  • Maximum number of tags per resource - 50.

  • For each resource, each tag key must be unique, and each tag key can have only one value.

  • Maximum key length - 128 Unicode characters in UTF-8.

  • Maximum value length - 256 Unicode characters in UTF-8.

  • If your tagging schema is used across multiple services and resources, remember that other services may have restrictions on allowed characters. Generally allowed characters are: letters, numbers, and spaces representable in UTF-8, and the following characters: + - = . _ : / @.

  • Tag keys and values are case sensitive.

  • Do not use aws:, AWS:, or any upper or lowercase combination of such as a prefix for keys as it is reserved for AWS use. You cannot edit or delete tag keys with this prefix. Values can have this prefix. If a tag value has aws as its prefix but the key does not, then Forecast considers it to be a user tag and will count against the limit of 50 tags. Tags with only the key prefix of aws do not count against your tags per resource limit.

trainingDataEndTime.documentation: The end date and time of the training window.

trainingDataStartTime.documentation: The start date and time of the training window.

trainingDatasetArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the training dataset for this audience model.

audienceModelArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the audience model.
The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the audience model to use for the configured audience model.

audienceSizeConfig.documentation: Configure the list of output sizes of audiences that can be created using this configured audience model. A request to StartAudienceGenerationJob that uses this configured audience model must have an audienceSize selected from this list. You can use the ABSOLUTE AudienceSize to configure out audience sizes using the count of identifiers in the output. You can use the Percentage AudienceSize to configure sizes in the range 1-100 percent.

childResourceTagOnCreatePolicy.documentation:
Configure how the service tags audience generation jobs created using this configured audience model. If you specify NONE, the tags from the StartAudienceGenerationJob request determine the tags of the audience generation job. If you specify FROM_PARENT_RESOURCE, the audience generation job inherits the tags from the configured audience model, by default. Tags in the StartAudienceGenerationJob will override the default.

When the client is in a different account than the configured audience model, the tags from the client are never applied to a resource in the caller's account.

description.documentation: The description of the configured audience model.

minMatchingSeedSize.documentation: The minimum number of users from the seed audience that must match with users in the training data of the audience model.

name.documentation: The name of the configured audience model.

outputConfig.documentation: Configure the Amazon S3 location and IAM Role for audiences created using this configured audience model. Each audience will have a unique location. The IAM Role must have s3:PutObject permission on the destination Amazon S3 location. If the destination is protected with Amazon S3 KMS-SSE, then the Role must also have the required KMS permissions.

tags.documentation:
The optional metadata that you apply to the resource to help you categorize and organize them. Each tag consists of a key and an optional value, both of which you define.

The following basic restrictions apply to tags:

  • Maximum number of tags per resource - 50.

  • For each resource, each tag key must be unique, and each tag key can have only one value.

  • Maximum key length - 128 Unicode characters in UTF-8.

  • Maximum value length - 256 Unicode characters in UTF-8.

  • If your tagging schema is used across multiple services and resources, remember that other services may have restrictions on allowed characters. Generally allowed characters are: letters, numbers, and spaces representable in UTF-8, and the following characters: + - = . _ : / @.

  • Tag keys and values are case sensitive.

  • Do not use aws:, AWS:, or any upper or lowercase combination of such as a prefix for keys as it is reserved for AWS use. You cannot edit or delete tag keys with this prefix. Values can have this prefix. If a tag value has aws as its prefix but the key does not, then Forecast considers it to be a user tag and will count against the limit of 50 tags. Tags with only the key prefix of aws do not count against your tags per resource limit.

configuredAudienceModelArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the configured audience model.

name.documentation: The name of the training dataset. This name must be unique in your account and region.

roleArn.documentation:
The ARN of the IAM role that Clean Rooms ML can assume to read the data referred to in the dataSource field of each dataset.

Passing a role across AWS accounts is not allowed. If you pass a role that isn't in your account, you get an AccessDeniedException error.

tags.documentation:
The optional metadata that you apply to the resource to help you categorize and organize them. Each tag consists of a key and an optional value, both of which you define.

The following basic restrictions apply to tags:

  • Maximum number of tags per resource - 50.

  • For each resource, each tag key must be unique, and each tag key can have only one value.

  • Maximum key length - 128 Unicode characters in UTF-8.

  • Maximum value length - 256 Unicode characters in UTF-8.

  • If your tagging schema is used across multiple services and resources, remember that other services may have restrictions on allowed characters. Generally allowed characters are: letters, numbers, and spaces representable in UTF-8, and the following characters: + - = . _ : / @.

trainingData.documentation: An array of information that lists the Dataset objects, which specifies the dataset type and details on its location and schema. You must provide a role that has read access to these tables.

trainingDatasetArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the training dataset resource.

glueDataSource.documentation: A GlueDataSource object that defines the catalog ID, database name, and table name for the training data.

DataSource.documentation: Defines information about the Glue data source that contains the training data.

inputConfig.documentation: A DatasetInputConfig object that defines the data source and schema mapping.

type.documentation: What type of information is found in the dataset.

Dataset.documentation: Defines where the training dataset is located, what type of data it contains, and how to access the data.

dataSource.documentation: A DataSource object that specifies the Glue data source for the training data.

schema.documentation: The schema information for the training data.

DatasetInputConfig.documentation: Defines the Glue data source and schema mapping information.

audienceGenerationJobArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the audience generation job that you want to delete.

audienceModelArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the audience model that you want to delete.

configuredAudienceModelArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the configured audience model policy that you want to delete.
The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the configured audience model that you want to delete.

audienceGenerationJobArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the audience generation job that you are interested in.
The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the audience generation job.

collaborationId.documentation: The identifier of the collaboration that this audience generation job is associated with.

configuredAudienceModelArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the configured audience model used for this audience generation job.

createTime.documentation: The time at which the audience generation job was created.

description.documentation: The description of the audience generation job.

includeSeedInOutput.documentation: Configure whether the seed users are included in the output audience. By default, Clean Rooms ML removes seed users from the output audience. If you specify TRUE, the seed users will appear first in the output. Clean Rooms ML does not explicitly reveal whether a user was in the seed, but the recipient of the audience will know that the first minimumSeedSize count of users are from the seed.

metrics.documentation: The relevance scores for different audience sizes.

name.documentation: The name of the audience generation job.

seedAudience.documentation: The seed audience that was used for this audience generation job. This field will be null if the account calling the API is the account that started this audience generation job.

startedBy.documentation: The AWS account that started this audience generation job.

status.documentation: The status of the audience generation job.

statusDetails.documentation: Details about the status of the audience generation job.

tags.documentation: The tags that are associated to this audience generation job.

updateTime.documentation: The most recent time at which the audience generation job was updated.

audienceModelArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the audience model that you are interested in.
The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the audience model.

createTime.documentation: The time at which the audience model was created.

kmsKeyArn.documentation: The KMS key ARN used for the audience model.

statusDetails.documentation: Details about the status of the audience model.

tags.documentation: The tags that are assigned to the audience model.

trainingDataEndTime.documentation: The end date specified for the training window.

trainingDataStartTime.documentation: The start date specified for the training window.

trainingDatasetArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the training dataset that was used for this audience model.

updateTime.documentation: The most recent time at which the audience model was updated.

configuredAudienceModelArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the configured audience model that you are interested in.
The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the configured audience model.

configuredAudienceModelPolicy.documentation: The configured audience model policy. This is a JSON IAM resource policy.

policyHash.documentation: A cryptographic hash of the contents of the policy used to prevent unexpected concurrent modification of the policy.

configuredAudienceModelArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the configured audience model that you are interested in.

audienceModelArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the audience model used for this configured audience model.

audienceSizeConfig.documentation: The list of output sizes of audiences that can be created using this configured audience model. A request to StartAudienceGenerationJob that uses this configured audience model must have an audienceSize selected from this list. You can use the ABSOLUTE AudienceSize to configure out audience sizes using the count of identifiers in the output. You can use the Percentage AudienceSize to configure sizes in the range 1-100 percent.

The optional metadata that you apply to the resource to help you categorize and organize them. Each tag consists of a key and an optional value, both of which you define.

The following basic restrictions apply to tags:

  • Maximum number of tags per resource - 50.

  • For each resource, each tag key must be unique, and each tag key can have only one value.

  • Maximum key length - 128 Unicode characters in UTF-8.

  • Maximum value length - 256 Unicode characters in UTF-8.

  • If your tagging schema is used across multiple services and resources, remember that other services may have restrictions on allowed characters. Generally allowed characters are: letters, numbers, and spaces representable in UTF-8, and the following characters: + - = . _ : / @.

  • Tag keys and values are case sensitive.

  • Do not use aws:, AWS:, or any upper or lowercase combination of such as a prefix for keys as it is reserved for AWS use. You cannot edit or delete tag keys with this prefix. Values can have this prefix. If a tag value has aws as its prefix but the key does not, then Forecast considers it to be a user tag and will count against the limit of 50 tags. Tags with only the key prefix of aws do not count against your tags per resource limit.

audienceGenerationJobArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the audience generation job.

message.documentation: The error message that was returned. The message is intended for human consumption and can change at any time. Use the statusCode for programmatic error handling.

statusCode.documentation: The status code that was returned. The status code is intended for programmatic error handling. Clean Rooms ML will not change the status code for existing error conditions.

StatusDetails.documentation: Details about the status of a resource.

resourceArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the resource that you want to assign tags.

createTime.documentation: The time at which the training dataset was created.

minMatchingSeedSize.documentation: The minimum number of users from the seed audience that must match with users in the training data of the audience model.

sharedAudienceMetrics.documentation: The new value for whether to share audience metrics.

configuredAudienceModelArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the configured audience model that was updated.

ValidationException.documentation: The request parameters for this request are incorrect.

documentation:
Welcome to the Amazon Web Services Clean Rooms ML API Reference.

Amazon Web Services Clean Rooms ML provides a privacy-enhancing method for two parties to identify similar users in their data without the need to share their data with each other. The first party brings the training data to Clean Rooms so that they can create and configure an audience model (lookalike model) and associate it with a collaboration. The second party then brings their seed data to Clean Rooms and generates an audience (lookalike segment) that resembles the training data.

To learn more about Amazon Web Services Clean Rooms ML concepts, procedures, and best practices, see the Clean Rooms User Guide.

To learn more about SQL commands, functions, and conditions supported in Clean Rooms, see the Clean Rooms SQL Reference.
